content:
The statement has a very frustrating error:
> "If the final result is greater than 24, it will display 0, like 86400=24:00:00=00:00:00"

What you mean is that it will display as [hour] % 24, so 25:00:00 will give 01:00:00.

None of the test cases cover this issue of values > 24, so clashers are left to guess whether you actually implemented this as the statement says "display 0", or as [hour] % 24, which is the only way to get 100%.

:/
I just lost to some bots because I followed the misleading instructions.

"If the final result is greater than 24, it will display 0, like 86400=24:00:00=00:00:00"

Validator 2 has a final result greater than 24 and it does not display 0.
It displays the result %24, which is 1.
Please either fix the validator or the description, because there is no test that would let people know that it doesn't follow the stated rule.

These artificial rules (13 -> "EE"; if result > 24, display 0, ...) make it unsolvable for reverse. And tbh they make no sense. It's like "oops, there already might be another clash converting seconds to time, so let's make it different by adding some arbitrary stuff".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This puzzle is easy and fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this task, encouraging coders to use modules like time module

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's an acceptable clash of code.  a bit easy, but okay.

Nice quick puzzle.

Here is my solution

exec(bytes('㵳椠瑮椨灮瑵⤨਩㵭⽳㘯ਰ㵳╳〶栊⠽⽭㘯⤰㈥਴㵭╭〶瀊楲瑮昨笢㩨㈰㩽浻〺紲笺㩳㈰≽爮灥慬散∨㌱Ⱒ䔢≅⤩','u16')[2:])
I like it!, Probably should specify after 12:00 Midnight
and regarding "if the final result is greater than 24, it will display 0" - that's not even what the proposed solution does..

I've edited the description to now read:
If the final result hour is greater than 24, it should display as hour % 24, like 86400=24:00:00=00:00:00
